reviewText: I first saw THE GREEN MAN when it was broadcast back in 1992 on A&E; when it really stood for Arts & Entertainment. I'm always on the lookout for a good ghost story movie. I'll take it over your average horror film any day of the week. This one is more than just a good ghost story, it's a great one which incorporates the legend of the celtic Green Man into a modern setting. It's based on a novel by Kingsley Amis and stars Albert Finney in a typically charismatic performance. He plays Maurice Allington, the owner of a historic English inn who is oversexed and seriously alcoholic. When he begins having dreams and hallucinations about a forest spirit and a ghost dressed in 18th century clothing he puts it down to drink only to discover that it's all too real when the ghost causes the death of his father and goes after his teenage daughter. Throw in a significant subplot of his roving eye, an unhappy marriage, and a visit from God in a white blazer with a cocktail glass and you have an intelligent, engaging narrative for adults most of the time.Despite all of these assets, THE GREEN MAN is not without its flaws. At 150 minutes, it's simply too long and suffers from pacing problems and inconsistant segues. The adult relationships subplot seems there only for the sake of making the story contemporary and for adding to the length but, to be fair, I haven't read Amis' novel where I'm sure it fits in better than it seems to here. Of course Finney is very good at playing troubled characters from the creepy remake of NIGHT MUST FALL (1964) through his stunning portrayal of the alcoholic diplomat in UNDER THE VOLCANO (1984). The scene where he stares at the woman in the shower and then his reaction is the equal of Jack Nicholson's in THE SHINING. The rest of the cast is solid with a nice turn from Michael Hordern as Finney's father and a chilling portrayal from Michael Culver as the ghost. The biggest problem though is not with the movie, but with the format. It's only available in America on VHS. There is a Region 2 DVD but in this day and age it needs to be on Region 1.

reviewText: I have this DVD, which I obtained from the U.K., and recommend it to all viewers. If you can, try and get a copy of this film on either DVD, or VHS, it is well worth the time and money. This excellent BBC film, first aired in 1992. [In the USA]. The entire film is outstanding! Maurice Allington (Albert Finney) is a womanizing  alcoholic, and the owner of the "Green Man Inn."  When his father dies, he begins to see someone no one else can. Everyone shrugs it off as too much drink. However, there is something amiss at the Green Man Inn. Only Lucy, his young daughter believes that he is seeing something from another spiritual plane. His wife and friends believe that the alcohol is finally affecting his mind. Including his Doctor. And more importantly, a clergyman too!One of the main attractions of the Green Man Inn is the supposedly haunted stories that Maurice regales in telling visitors when they come to dine there. However, things are no longer funny when he begins to see more and more visions of one ghost in particular. When he begins to dig deeper into the history of his family estate, he discovers that an evil man, Dr. Underhill (Michael Culver) was a murderer who killed his wife in a most horrible manner. This Dr. Underhill lived in the 17th century. The spirit of this evil man makes contact with Maurice and promises him the world, if he will only do one thing for him. I will not divulge this and spoil the film for you. I highly recommend this excellent film. [Stars: 5+]
summary: EXCELLENT GHOST STORY OF AN EVIL SPIRIT!

reviewText: The Green Man is a 14th-century-built country inn some miles outside Cambridge toward London, allegedly haunted with the ghost of its 17th-century proprietor, Dr. Thomas Underhill (DD; Michael Culver, Cadfael's Prior Robert).  Dr. Underhill was a discredited cleric who dabbled in the occult, mixing potions facilitating his unlimited sexual access to numerous pre-pubescent girls ("O quae deliciae!").  As local clerics refused to officiate at his 1695 funeral, he was buried by outsiders from Cambridge in the back corner of the local cemetery.  His wife, occasionally seen as a ghost, died under vividly explicit demonic circumstances in the nearby isolated wood cove.  Maurice Allington (Albert Finney) is the present-day upscale inn's (highly-respected restaurant plus rooms) middle-aged live-in proprietor; an alcoholic battling DTs and insatiable sex drives; who capitalizes on this infamous legend to promote the inn's tourist business.  To Allington's astonishment the legend is true: the inn really is haunted by Dr. Underhill, his wife, and sundry evil spirits prowling the grounds and wood cove and from whom Underhill curried favors via an evil silver amulet.  Even God (disguised as Philip Franks) puts in an appearance.This 1990 150-minute TV adaptation, directed by Elijah Moshinsky and originally broadcast by BBC as three fifty-minute segments, was adapted for TV by Malcolm Bradbury from Kingsley Amis' (1922 - 1995) 1969 novel.  Picture stability, sharpness, color and contrast are excellent for this twenty-year-old production!  This viewer could detect absolutely no grain using a 1080p LCD (Sony Bravia 32XBR6); with Pioneer Elite DVD Player DV-59AV; and a 'COM WORLD Digital Video Converter System', a PAL-to-NTSC conversion box which, during conversion, introduces faint rolling-band artifacts in several low-light (night-time muted-color) scenes.  Sound is fine with optional easily-read English subtitles.Viewers have the MENU option of setting subtitles and viewing the three parts separately, each part with full introductory and closing credits as originally aired and divided into eight unnamed chapters (which are not on the menu but can be stepped through at will); or viewing ALL which amounts to the same thing sans breaks between the parts.There is no 'officially sanctioned' NTSC Region 1 DVD of this (4x3 aspect) TV production; only underground bootlegged copies with their substantial picture and sound quality flaws.  BEWARE THIS IS A PAL REGION 2 DVD (!!!) AND MAY NOT PLAY ON YOUR REGULAR PLAYER!  The powers that be (this side of the pond) presumed normal American audiences would be bored stiff by this film, hence their making no money.  They may be right:  ATTENTION 13-YEAR-OLDS (and those who feel that way):  As a film of exquisitely delicious adult situations and predicaments (I'm not using 'adult' as co-opted by the porn industry!), you would find The Green Man excruciatingly disappointing:  no plot dumbing-down; no jittery or spinning camera angles; no f-words; no impossible gun shootouts or car chases; and most importantly, no gratuitously explicit mandatory sex scenes.This reviewer never tires of watching this film at least once or twice a year with its intricate plot, brilliant dialog, dry wit, depth and excellence of the actors, first class direction, good musical score, and fine TV production values: intelligent film-making at its zenith!  My highest recommendation.

reviewText: I first saw this film on A&E in 1992, and was impressed with it. The combination of gothic horror, light comedy and drama made this somewhat lengthy film a treat to watch. Unfortunately it is not availaible on DVD and it's even hard to find on VHS. My copy's slip cover is worn and well used. I recommend this movie to any horror fan, who appreciates a good story without the intense gore and shallow dialogue.  Albert Finney is PERFECT in this role as the boozing, womanizing inn-keeper in the English countryside.  Watch for the "visitor" in the latter half, and try and come to your OWN to conclusion what character he is playing in the story.  Enjoy!
